intro: Dactylorhiza kerryensis, commonly known as Kerry orchid, is a rare and endangered species native to the western and northwestern regions of Ireland. It is a terrestrial orchid with a slender, upright stem and a single, showy flower that typically blooms in late summer. The plant has lance-shaped leaves and is adapted to grow in moist, calcareous soils. It is part of the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its unique floral structure and specific pollination mechanisms. Due to habitat loss and environmental changes, conservation efforts are crucial for its survival.
